hedline.hl1: Suffolk Legislators Vote For Four-Year Terms

abstract.p: Suffolk County lawmakers, voting 10 to 8, approve resolution to extend their terms of office from two years to four; measure, if approved by County Executive Robert Gaffney, would take effect in November 2003 (M)

block.p: Suffolk County legislators approved a resolution last week that would extend their terms of office from two years to four. The measure, which passed by a vote of 10 to 8, now goes to Robert J. Gaffney, the county executive. A spokeswoman, Cecilia M. Clausing, said Mr. Gaffney was reviewing it and had not taken a position. The votes of two-thirds of the 18 legislators would be needed to override a veto.
The term extension will also need the approval of Suffolk voters in a referendum in November. The new system would take effect in November 2003.

Suffolk County legislators approved a resolution last week that would extend their terms of office from two years to four. The measure, which passed by a vote of 10 to 8, now goes to Robert J. Gaffney, the county executive. A spokeswoman, Cecilia M. Clausing, said Mr. Gaffney was reviewing it and had not taken a position. The votes of two-thirds of the 18 legislators would be needed to override a veto.
The term extension will also need the approval of Suffolk voters in a referendum in November. The new system would take effect in November 2003.

The sponsor of the measure, Jon Cooper, Democrat of Lloyd Harbor, said longer terms would free legislators from the cost and time involved in running for re-election every two years. The longer term would also give legislators more time to study and address complex issues, he said. ''With a four-year term, legislators are free to implement policies that will benefit communities, rather than just putting a temporary patch on the problem,'' he said.

David Bishop of West Babylon, the Democratic minority leader, said he opposed the measure. ''Mr. Cooper has the best of intentions,'' he said, ''but I think they are outweighed by the fact that government would move further away from the people.''
The county legislators earn $71,381 a year. The presiding officer, whom they elect, earns $87,243, and the deputy presiding officer earns $79,312.
The 19 members of the Nassau County Legislature serve two-year terms. Fran Evans, a spokeswoman for the Democratic majority there, said that no measure to extend the terms had been proposed.
